newsitem.title: USA: CBOT corn ends up on export ideas, bull spreading.
newsitem.headline: CBOT corn ends up on export ideas, bull spreading.

text.p: CBOT corn futures closed higher on commercial buying and bull spreading which led to ideas that a significant amount of corn export business had been accomplished, traders said.
"Commercial buying in wheat and corn kept the market up all day. There was no fresh news other than a continuation of a good technical performance," said Mark Cermak of O'Connor and Co.
Contract lows were set early this week but the market then began a reticent climb on daily charts and the cash-related buying Thursday and Friday helped fuel bullish fervor.

Continental Grain led the buy side with bull spreads of at least 14 million bushels Friday, traders said. Continental did five million bushels each of Dec/Mar and Mar/May and spread four million May/July, sources said. Continental also was a net buyer of two million December, they said. Cargill Inc bought eight million bushels of December and Cargill Investor Services bought 3,500 March $2.50 puts and sold 3,500 March $2.70 puts in the corn options pit, traders said.
Continental Thursday bull spread 10.0 million bushels.
Corn closed three cents per bushel higher to 1/4 lower, with December up three at $2.67-1/2.
Prospects for further fund short covering also helped advance the nearby corn futures contracts, the traders said.
"It was a weekly reversal in corn charts and they're looking for a big spec short in the corn market tonight," Cermak said.
Traders said the updated Commodity Futures Trading Commission Commitments of Traders report slated for release late Friday was expected to show a strong bias to the short side of corn by key funds.
Firm cash basis values with the Chicago market said trading at 14 cents over the December, boosted prices.
Traders also said short covering helped buoy corn with players taking positions ahead of Tuesday's USDA November crop production report.

But the Leslie-ADM Elevator survey released early Friday cast a bit of bearish light on futures. Leslie estimated the 1996 U.S. corn crop would total 9.22 billion bushels. The estimate exceeded the average of analysts' estimates in a Reuter survey of 9.145 billion bushels.
Corn futures volume was estimated at 69,000 contracts, below the 83,758 traded Thursday, according to the CBOT.
Corn options volume was estimated at 25,000 contracts, down from 28,542 Thursday.
